comment._content: Helen May Valk Borden sued her millionaire husband Gail Borden for divorce in 1911, in Los Angeles; his money came from a condensed-milk fortune. The divorce was finally granted in 1914. news.google.com/newspapers?id=F5YxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3SAEA... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50611F63B5517738... Big drama. At some point in the difficult divorce process, Helen placed her daughter Ramona in a New Jersey sanitarium/boarding school, to hide her from Gail; then Gail's people kidnapped Ramona from the sanitarium, or maybe she ran away; either way, she turned up in Boston a few days later: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40713FB3C5B13738... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60F12F83C5B13738... Alexine Ramona Borden (b. 1896) married in 1916, to Cole Parker, at her maternal grandparents' home: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F50915FE345B17... Gail Borden remarried in January 1916, to Margaret B. Coutaint of Pittsburgh. So this is maybe Margaret rather than Helen.
